metadata.title: SARS-CoV-2 prolonged infection during advanced HIV disease evolves extensive immune escape

body_text.text: We next characterized SARS-CoV-2 that had evolved in a person with advanced HIV diagnosed 140 in late September 2020 with SARS-CoV-2 infected with the ancestral lineage B.1.1.273 which we 141 previously described in a case report (Karim et al., 2021b) . The study participant was discharged 142 9 days post-diagnosis according to South Africa guidelines and remained asymptomatic for most 143 study visits (see description in the Materials and methods). HIV viremia persisted up to day 190 144 post-diagnosis due to irregular ART adherence. SARS-CoV-2 titer was high throughout this 145 period, ranging from a Ct of 16 to 27 (Karim et al., 2021b) . Last positive qPCR result was early 146 May 2021. Phylogenetic mapping is consistent with a single infection event (Fig 1B) . The CD4 147 count was <10 at enrollment (Fig 2A top row) . It increased at later timepoints, possibly due to the 148 improved adherence to ART and a switch to dolutegravir based therapy which reduced the HIV 149 viral load to below the level of clinical detection (Karim et al., 2021b) . SARS-CoV-2 was detected 150 by qPCR until day 216 post-diagnosis (Fig 2A second row) . We attempted to isolate live virus up 151 to and including the day 216 post-diagnosis swab sample. While there was insufficient sample to 152 isolate virus from the day 0 swab, we isolated and expanded SARS-CoV-2 from subsequent 153 swabs until and including day 190 post-SARS-CoV-2 diagnosis (Fig 2A third row) . Successful 154 isolation indicates that live virus was shed at that time. RBD specific IgG antibodies in the blood 155 were at borderline detection levels (slightly above the mean negative control + 2 std) at the early 156 timepoints but were detected at higher levels starting day 190 (Fig 2A fourth row, Fig S1 related  157 to Fig 2A) . 158 159 Outgrown virus was sequenced to detect majority and minority variants (Fig 2B) . The mutations 160 found in the outgrown virus were representative of the virus in the swab from the matched time 161 point (Table S2 related during expansion in Vero E6 cells and likely confers moderate neutralization escape (Johnson et 165 al., 2021) . E484K was first detected in the day 6 isolate (Fig 2B) . This mutation persisted at day 166 20 and 34 but was replaced with the F490S substitution starting on day 71 when the K417T 167 mutation was also detected. The N501Y mutation was detected in the virus isolated on day 190 168 post-diagnosis. Mutations were clustered in the RBD, including K417T, F490S, and N501Y in the 169 day 190 viral isolate ( Fig 2C) . Among the RBD mutations in the day 190 isolate, K417T is found 170 in the Gamma variant, and F490S is found in the Lambda variant. Among NTD mutations, T95I 171 is found in Mu, and R190K is at the same location as the R190S in Gamma. N501Y is found in 172

Beta, among others. The Omicron variant has emerged as this work was being revised and has 173 J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f mutations at many of the same sites as the evolving virus described here 174 (https://covdb.stanford.edu/page/mutation-viewer/#sec_b-1-351). This includes the D796Y 175 mutation only found in Omicron among the major variants ( Fig 2B) . 176 177 We tested three of the isolates for neutralization: viruses outgrown from day 6 and day 20 swabs 178 (designated D6, D20) representing viruses from early infection, and virus outgrown from the day 179 190 swab (D190), after substantial evolution. Neutralization of the D6, D20, and D190 isolates by 180 self-plasma was low at the early timepoints ( Fig 2D) . However, neutralization of D6 and D20 was 181 evident by plasma sampled from day 190 and was more pronounced in the plasma sampled from 182 day 216. The D6 isolate was the most sensitive to neutralization by day 216 plasma. Neutralization 183 declined for D20 and further for D190, suggesting sequential evolution of escape ( Fig 2D) . The 184 ancestral virus and Beta and Delta variants were also tested for neutralization using day 216 185 plasma. Neutralization was lower for all three non-self viral strains relative to self-derived virus. 186
The strongest neutralization was of ancestral virus. Delta was neutralized to a lesser degree, and 187
Beta was not detectably neutralized ( Fig 2D) . 188

We also tested the D6, D20, and D190 isolates against plasma from other convalescent 190 participants infected with ancestral virus. Neutralization of D190 by ancestral infection elicited 191 plasma was decreased dramatically relative to D6, with FRNT50 for D190 being 9.3-fold lower 192 despite the presence of the E484K mutation in D6 ( Figure 2E ). The difference was smaller 193 between D190 and D20 (5.1-fold, Figure 2F ), consistent with evolution of some neutralization 194 escape in D20 relative to D6. We also tested neutralization of D190 virus using Pfizer BNT162b2 195 vaccinated participants. BNT162b2-elicited plasma neutralization capacity was decreased 5-fold 196 against D190 relative to ancestral virus with the D614G mutation ( Fig 2G) . We compared 197 neutralization of Beta, D6, D20, and D190 on a subset of remaining BNT162b2 plasma samples 198 from 5 participants 5-6 months post-vaccine, where neutralization declined to relatively low levels. 199

Despite this limitation, neutralization was detectable and showed a pattern consistent with the 200 other results: D190 neutralization escape was very similar to Beta, while D6 and D20 showed no 201 escape from BNT162b2 elicited neutralization (Fig S2 related to Fig 2G) . A 5-fold reduction is less 202 than the fold-drop we obtained for the Beta variant with convalescent plasma from previous 203 infection (Cele et al., 2021a) and these results are consistent with substantial but incomplete 204 escape of D190 from BNT162b2 elicited immunity. 205 206 J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f We next assessed the serological distance between D190, D6, the ancestral strain, Beta, Delta, 207

and Alpha variants. We tested against convalescent plasma obtained from participants infected 208 with ancestral strains or Beta or Delta variants. Neutralization by ancestral plasma immunity 209 declined 8.8-fold relative to ancestral virus for the D190 isolate (Fig 2H) , similar to the Beta variant. 210

In contrast, there was only a 1.6-fold decline for the D6 isolate ( Fig 2I) . D190 virus was neutralized 211 relatively well by Beta variant infection elicited plasma, with a 2.6-fold reduction (Fig 2J) . This was 212 similar to D6 neutralization, which was reduce 2.3-fold relative to Beta (Fig 2K) . A much more 213 dramatic decline was observed with Delta variant elicited immunity: a 27.1-fold drop in 214 neutralization capacity compared to neutralization of Delta virus (Fig 2L) . Escape from Delta 215 elicited immunity was much more moderate for D6, with a 5.4-fold decline compared to Delta virus 216 ( Fig 2M) . 217

Mapping the results ( Fig 2N) shows that the Beta and Delta variants are serologically far apart, 219 with ancestral virus forming a hub. The greater distance of Beta relative to Delta from ancestral 220 is consistent with Beta being an escape variant and so evolving antibody escape mutations in the 221 RBD as well as mutations and deletions in the NTD. The Alpha variant was serologically like the 222 ancestral strain and was well neutralized by Beta plasma. However, it did escape Delta elicited 223 neutralization. D6 was serologically similar to the ancestral strain even though it had the E484K 224 substitution (and the in vitro evolved R682W which is reported to confer a moderate decrease in 225 neutralization). In contrast, the D190 virus, which underwent extensive evolution, was 226 serologically like Beta despite sequence differences. It had escape from ancestral and a much 227 more pronounced escape from Delta elicited plasma, similar to the Beta virus. We did not map 228

Gamma, but neutralization escape of the Delta but not the Beta variant from Gamma elicited 229 neutralization (Liu et al., 2021) Antigenic cartography has been extensively used in influenza (Smith et al., 2004) . Genetic 258 distance may be partially but not completely a proxy for antigenic distance, as some substitutions 259 can lead to large changes in antigenicity while others lead to minor effects (Smith et al., 2004) . It 260 is unclear whether genetic distance is a good measure for antigenic differences between SARS-261

CoV-2 variants. For example, based on the phylogenetic tree ( Fig 1B) it is not obvious that Beta 262 elicited immunity would neutralize Alpha virus better than Delta immunity. Perhaps this is because 263 SARS-CoV-2 evolution seems be closer to HIV, where multiple strains radiate from a common 264 ancestor (Korber et al., 2000) , than to the stepwise progression in influenza (Smith et al., 2004) . Characteristics of convalescent participants with ancestral, Beta, or Delta variant infection whose 371 blood was used for neutralization experiments can be found in Table S1 , and Pfizer BNT162b2 372 vaccinated blood donor characteristics can be found in Table S4 .

FIGREF1.text: not differ. Therefore, cross-neutralization of ancestral virus by Beta immunity is 245 effective. Delta and Beta do differ at class 3 sites, possibly leading to Delta escape of Beta 246 immunity and vice versa. Differences in the NTD would further decrease cross-neutralization. 247 248 The driving force behind the evolution of D190 may have been the presence of very low levels of 249 antibody to SARS-CoV-2 which may select for antibody escape mutations without the ability to 250 clear the infection. While the participant described here did develop a neutralization response and 251 did clear the virus, the response was strongest against the ancestral-like virus early in infection 252and weak for the Beta-like D190 isolate, indicating a considerable lag between SARS-CoV-2 253 evolution and neutralization. Consistent with this, neutralization was detectable for the ancestral 254 strain but not Beta virus. This may be a source of vulnerability for future SARS-CoV-

FIGREF2.text: 265How far the variants will diverge from each other is unclear, but if further divergence occurs, 266 SARS-CoV-2 may form serotypes such as occur with polio(Minor et al., 1986) and dengue 267(Guzman et al., 2007) viruses. With serotypes, antibody immunity is developed to the infecting 268 but not the other serotypes. This may imply that a vaccine which is based on one variant or strain 269 or previous infection with that variant may generate immunity which is vulnerable to infection surprised us in the participant from whom we derived the viral isolates was that, over the 6-273 month period where SARS-CoV-2 titer was high, infection was for the most part asymptomatic. 274 J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f One explanation is that the virus evolved attenuated pathogenicity or had low pathogenicity to 275 begin with. This would account for the mild disease which allowed the individual harboring the 276 infection to survive and the virus to evolve. Another explanation may be that high pathogen levels 277 are tolerated because immunosuppression reduces the inflammatory response. This latter 278 scenario is observed in tuberculosis(Meintjes et al., 2018).279 280 As this work was being revised, the Omicron variant has been detected in South Africa hand has 281 spread globally. Omicron (B.1.1.529) is derived from strains which were common in the first 282 infection wave in South Africa, 1.5 years ago, but were then supplanted first by Beta, then Delta. 283 There may be several possibilities for how this virus persisted so long without being detected. 284 One explanation is that Omicron may have evolved in a region with less developed genomic 285 surveillance relative to South Africa and may have arrived in South Africa recently. Alternatively 286 and without excluding the former possibility, it may have persisted in a single immune 287 compromised host until it acquired a critical mass of mutations that would allow it to effectively 288 transmit in a population where the prevalence of previous infection is high (Khan et al., 2021, 289 Sykes et al., 2021). In support of this, previous studies investigating SARS-CoV-2 evolution in 290 people immune-compromised for reasons other than advanced HIV disease have established 291 that such evolution leads to immune escape mutations (Chen et al., 2021, Clark et al., 2021). 292 Therefore, evolution of escape is not related directly to HIV but rather to severe damage to the 293 immune response from long-term, poorly suppressed HIV infection. If the evolved viral strain 294 described in this work and Omicron share a common evolutionary mechanism, other features 295 could also be shared, such as potentially mild pathogenicity (Goga et al., 2021, Jassat et al.) 296 which could account for long-term persistence in a single host. of this study is that we have characterized one case. Out of 93 PLWH in our cohort at 301 the time of analysis (Karim et al., 2021a), 13 had persistent CD4<200 but only one (~1%) showed 302 extensive evolution of SARS-CoV-2 as described here. However, as there are about 8 million 303 PLWH in South Africa, (https://www.unaids.org/en/regionscountries/countries/southafrica), 304 assuming a frequency of 1% would translate to 80,000 people where SARS-CoV-2 evolution 305 could occur. We have previously reported on a 2-fold drop in the number of SARS-CoV-2 306 convalescents suppressed with antiretroviral therapy in the second versus first infection wave in 307 Sequence of outgrown virus has been deposited in GISAID. Raw images of the data are 327 available upon reasonable request. 328 329  Image analysis and curve fitting scripts in MATLAB v.2019b are available on GitHub 330 (https://github.com/sigallab/NatureMarch2021). 331 Any additional information required to reanalyze the data reported in this paper is 333 available from the lead contact upon request except for identifying oropharyngeal swab samples and blood samples were obtained after written 340 informed consent from hospitalized adults with PCR-confirmed SARS-CoV-2 infection or 341 vaccinated individuals who were enrolled in a prospective cohort study approved by the 342 Biomedical Research Ethics Committee at the University of KwaZulu-Natal (reference 343 BREC/00001275/2020). The participant with advanced HIV disease described in this report was 344 enrolled under the same study (reference BREC/00001275/2020). We obtained additional written 345 informed consent for publication from the participant with advanced HIV disease. The Pfizer 346 BNT162b2 plasma was acquired from participants enrolled in the UWARN: COVIDadvanced HIV disease was a female in her late 30s symptomatic for Covid-19 352 admitted to a hospital in Durban, South Africa. Symptom onset was 12 days prior to hospital 353 admission. Participant was admitted to hospital in September 2020 with shortness of breath, sore 354 throat, and cough and administered non-high flow supplemental oxygen via face mask and a six-355 day course of dexamethasone. Study enrollment was in October 2020, 6 days post-admission, 356 and each study visit consisted of a blood draw and a combined nasopharyngeal and 357 oropharyngeal swab to detect and isolate SARS-CoV-2. Study visits occurred at enrollment, and 358 day 20, 34, 71, 106, 190, 204, 216, and 233 post-admission. Participant had been on ART since 359 2006, most recently a fixed-dose combination of tenofovir, emtricitabine and efavirenz. However, 360 ART components were not detected by liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry at 361 enrollment. Participant was discharged 9 days post-admission. On day 20 and day 34 post-362 admission, participant was asymptomatic. On day 71, she complained of chest tightness and 363 oxygen saturation decreased from 96% to 76% on exertion. Chest X-ray showed perihilar 364 infiltrates and participant was treated for Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP) as an outpatient with 365 21 days of co-trimoxazole and prednisone. She was reviewed on day 106 post-admission when 366 she reported fatigue, and on day 190 when she was asymptomatic. On day 190 post-admission, 367 ART was switched to a fixed-dose combination of tenofovir, lamivudine and dolutegravir. HIV viral 368 load was suppressed on day 204 post-admission. No symptoms were reported on day 190, 204, 369 216 or 233 post-admission. More information can be found in the case report (Karim et al., 2021b). 370

FIGREF3.text: cells (ATCC CRL-1586, obtained from Cellonex in South Africa) were propagated in 376 complete DMEM with 10% fetal bovine serum (Hylone) containing 1% each of HEPES, sodium 377 pyruvate, L-glutamine and nonessential amino acids (Sigma-Aldrich). Vero E6 cells were 378 passaged every 3-4 days. The H1299-E3 cell line for first-passage SARS-CoV-2 expansion, 379 derived as described in (Cele et al.,2021a), was propagated in complete RPMI with 10% fetal 380 bovine serum containing 1% each of HEPES, sodium pyruvate, L-glutamine and nonessential 381 amino acids. H1299 cells were passaged every second day. Cell lines have with live virus was performed in Biosafety Level 3 containment using protocols for SARS-387 CoV-2 approved by the AHRI Biosafety Committee. We used ACE2-expressing H1299-E3 cells 388 for the initial isolation (P1 stock) followed by passaging in Vero E6 cells (P2 and P3 stocks, where 389 P3 stock was used in experiments). ACE2-expressing H1299-E3 cells were seeded at 4.5 × 10 5 390 cells in a 6 well plate well and incubated for 18-20 h. After one DPBS wash, the sub-confluent 391 cell monolayer was inoculated with 500 μL universal transport medium diluted 1:1 with growth 392 medium filtered through a 0.45-μm filter. Cells were incubated for 1 h. Wells were then filled with 393 3 mL complete growth medium. After 8 days of infection, cells were trypsinized, centrifuged at 394 300 rcf for 3 min and resuspended in 4 mL growth medium. Then 1 mL was added to Vero E6 395 cells that had been seeded at 2 × 10 5 cells per mL 18-20 h earlier in a T25 flask (approximately 396 1:8 donor-to-target cell dilution ratio) for cell-to-cell infection. The coculture of ACE2-expressing 397 H1299-E3 and Vero E6 cells was incubated for 1 h and the flask was then filled with 7 mL of 398 complete growth medium and incubated for 6 days. The viral supernatant (P2 stock) was 399 aliquoted and stored at −80 °C and further passaged in Vero E6 cells to obtain the P3 genome sequencing, genome assembly and phylogenetic analysis 405 cDNA synthesis was performed on the extracted RNA using random primers followed by gene-406 specific multiplex PCR using the ARTIC V.3 protocol (https://www.protocols.io/view/covid-19-407 artic-v3-illumina-library-construction-an-bibtkann). In brief, extracted RNA was converted to cDNA 408 using the Superscript IV First Strand synthesis system (Life Technologies) and random hexamer 409 primers. SARS-CoV-2 whole-genome amplification was performed by multiplex PCR using410 primers designed using Primal Scheme (http://primal.zibraproject.org/) to generate 400-bp 411 amplicons with an overlap of 70 bp that covers the 30 kb SARS-CoV-2 genome. PCR products 412 were cleaned up using AmpureXP purification beads (Beckman Coulter) and quantified using the 413 Qubit dsDNA High Sensitivity assay on the Qubit 4.0 instrument (Life Technologies). We then 414 used the Illumina Nextera Flex DNA Library Prep kit according to the manufacturer'://www.genomedetective.com) and the Coronavirus Typing Tool. We polished the initial 421 assembly obtained from Genome Detective by aligning mapped reads to the reference sequences 422 and filtering out low-quality mutations using the bcftools 1.7-2 mpileup method. Mutations were 423 confirmed visually with BAM files using Geneious software (Biomatters). We analyzed sequences 424 from the six different time points (D6, D20, D34, D71, D106 and D190) against a global reference 425 dataset of 3883 genomes using a custom build of the SARS-CoV-2 NextStrain 426 (https://github.com/nextstrain/ncov). The workflow performs alignment of genomes, phylogenetic 427 tree inference, tree dating and ancestral state construction and annotation. The phylogenetic tree 428 was visualized using ggplot and ggtree. All sequences from the participant clustered in a 429 monophyletic clade (https://nextstrain.org/groups/ngs-sa/COVID19-AHRI-430 2021.05.27?label=clade:HIV%20patient) that are well separated from the rest of the phylogeny. cells were plated in a 96-well plate (Corning) at 30,000 cells per well 1 day pre-infection. 434 Plasma was separated from EDTA-anticoagulated blood by centrifugation at 500 rcf for 10 min 435 and stored at −80 °C. Aliquots of plasma samples were heat-inactivated at 56 °C for 30 min and 436 clarified by centrifugation at 10,000 rcf for 5 min. GenScript A02051 anti-spike neutralizing 437 monoclonal antibody was added as a positive control to one column of wells. Virus stocks were 438 used at approximately 50-100 focus-forming units per microwell and added to diluted plasma. 439 Antibody-virus mixtures were incubated for 1 h at 37 °C, 5% CO2. Cells were infected with 100 440 μL of the virus-antibody mixtures for 1 h, then 100 μL of a 1X RPMI 1640 (Sigma-Aldrich, R6504), 441 1.5% carboxymethylcellulose (Sigma-Aldrich, C4888) overlay was added without removing the 442 inoculum. Cells were fixed 18 h post-infection using 4% PFA (Sigma-Aldrich) for 20 min. Foci 443 were stained with a rabbit anti-spike monoclonal antibody (BS-R2B12, GenScript A02058) at 0.5 444 μg/mL in a permeabilization buffer containing 0.1% saponin (Sigma-Aldrich), 0.1% BSA (Sigma-445 Aldrich) and 0.05% Tween-20 (Sigma-Aldrich) in PBS. Plates were incubated with primary 446 antibody overnight at 4 °C, then washed with wash buffer containing 0.05% Tween-20 in PBS. 447 Secondary goat anti-rabbit horseradish peroxidase (Abcam ab205718) antibody was added at 1 448 μg/mL and incubated for 2 h at room temperature with shaking. TrueBlue peroxidase substrate 449 (SeraCare 5510-0030) was then added at 50 μL per well and incubated for 20 min at room 450 temperature. Plates were imaged in an ELISPOT instrument with built-in image analysis (C.T.CoV-2 pseudotyped lentiviruses were prepared by co-transfecting the HEK 293T cell line 454 with either the SARS-CoV-2 Beta spike (L18F, D80A, D215G, K417N, E484K, N501Y, D614G, 455 A701V, 242-244 del) or the Delta spike (T19R, R158G L452R, T478K, D614G, P681R, D950N, 456 156-157 del) plasmids in conjunction with a firefly luciferase encoding lentivirus backbone 457 plasmid. For the neutralization assay, heat-inactivated plasma samples from vaccine recipients 458 were incubated with the SARS-CoV-2 spike pseudotyped virus for 1 hour at 37°C, 5% CO2. 459 Subsequently, 1x10 4 HEK 293T cells engineered to over-express ACE-2 were added and 460 incubated at 37°C, 5% CO2 for 72 hours upon which the luminescence of the luciferase gene was 461 measured. CB6 antibody was used as a positive control. were tested for anti-SARS-CoV-2 IgG. Flat bottom microplates (ThermoFisher 465 Scientific) were coated with 500 ng/mL of the receptor binding domain (RBD) protein (provided 466 by Dr Galit Alter from the Ragon Institute) and incubated overnight at 4°C. Plates were blocked 467 with a 200 µL/well tris-buffered saline containing 1% BSA (TBSA) and incubated at room 468 temperature (RT) for 1h. Samples were diluted in TBSA with 0.05% Tween-20 (TBSAT) to 1:100. 469 Subsequently, goat anti-human IgG (1:5000)-horseradish peroxidase conjugated secondary 470 antibodies (Jackson ImmunoResearch) were added a 100 µL/well and incubated at RT for 1h. 471 Bound secondary antibodies were detected using 100 μL/well 1-step Ultra TMB substrate 472 (ThermoFisher Scientific). Plates were incubated at RT for 3 min in the dark before addition of 1 473 N sulphuric acid stop solution at 100 μL/well. Plates were washed with 1X high salt TBS containing 474 0.05% Tween-20, three times each after coating and blocking, and five times each after the 475 sample and secondary antibody. The concentration of anti-RBD expressed as ng/mL equivalent 476 of anti-SARS-CoV-2 monoclonal, CR3022 (Genscript). We used pre-pandemic plasma samples 477 as negative controls to define seroconversion cut-offs calculated as mean + is the number of foci normalized to the number of foci in the absence of plasma on the 489 same plate at dilution D and ID50 is the plasma dilution giving 50% neutralization. SC, and FK conceived the study and designed the study and experiments. SHH generated 494 plaque purified Beta variant virus. M-YSM, FK, BIG, KK, YG, MB, NM, MM, SWT, and WCVV set 495 up and managed the cohorts and cohort data. SC, JES, TH, HT, JS, TMG, EW, KK, LS, and JG 496 performed experiments and sequence analysis with input from AS, TdO, TN, WH, and RJL. AS, 497 SC, PLM, TdO, M-YSM, GL, SSAK and WCVV interpreted data. AS, GL, WCVV and PLM 498 prepared the manuscript with input from all authors.

FIGREF5.text: Neutralization distance between variants. (A) Infection waves and variant 870 frequencies in South Africa. (B) Maximum-likelihood phylogenetic tree with evolved virus 871 sequences (red) at 6 time-points in relation to 3883 global sequences with variants shown. (C-E) 872 Neutralization of the Beta (C), Delta (D) and Alpha (E) virus compared to D614G ancestral virus 873 by plasma from convalescent participants infected by ancestral strains (n=8). (F-G) Neutralization 874 of the Delta (F) and Alpha (G) compared to Beta virus by plasma from Beta infections (n=9). (H-875 I) Neutralization of the Beta (H) and Alpha (I) compared to Delta virus by plasma from Delta 876 infections (n=10). Experiments presented in panels C-I performed by a live virus neutralization 877 assay (LVNA). (J) Neutralization of Beta compared to Delta virus with the same plasma as (I) 878 using a pseudo-virus neutralization assay (PNA). Red horizontal line denotes most concentrated 879 plasma tested. Numbers in black above each virus strain are geometric mean titers (GMT) of the 880 reciprocal plasma dilution (FRNT50 for LVNA, ID50 for PNA) for 50% neutralization. Numbers in 881 red denote fold-change in GMT between virus strain on the left and the virus strain on the right. Mapping neutralization of variants and evolved virus. (A) Participant characteristics 886 over 233 days from SARS-CoV-2 diagnosis: CD4 T cell count (cells/µL), SARS-CoV-2 detection 887 by qPCR, virus outgrowth success, and presence of anti-RBD IgG. Because IgG levels were close 888to the background for some timepoints, they were marked as borderline. (

TABREF1.text: may suggest that Beta and Gamma are serologically similar.230    We have shown that Delta, Beta, Alpha, and the D190 virus we characterize here, are all escape 232 variants/strains in the sense that each can escape from neutralizing immunity elicited by at least 233 one other variant. This is even though D190 virus and Beta and Alpha variants predate Delta and 234 so escape from Delta immunity could not have been selected for. Furthermore, Delta shows weak 235 and Alpha no escape from immunity elicited by ancestral strains, indicating they may have 236 evolved to better transmit and not to escape. 237Escape between variants which was not selected for could happen because antibodies are 239 elicited to preferred sites on spike and these differ between variants. Antibodies against the RBD 240
